dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, I was reading this really interesting article, and, um, it totally blew my mind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, I was reading this really interesting article, and, um, it totally blew my mind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah? What's got you so, like, buzzing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah? What's got you so, like, buzzing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's about productivity. You know, how much we produce per hour worked. Turns out, the US has been totally lagging behind the Eurozone for, like, the last twenty years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's about productivity. You know, how much we produce per hour worked. Turns out, the U S has been totally lagging behind the Eurozone for, like, the last twenty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty years? Wow. I mean, I knew things were slow, but that long?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty years? Wow. I mean, I knew things were slow, but that long?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and get this: since the pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has actually *fallen* over six percent. Meanwhile, Europe's, uh, surged!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and get this: since the pandemic, U S non-farm output per hour has actually fallen over six percent. Meanwhile, Europe's, uh, surged!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's, like, catastrophic by our own historical standards, isn't it? So, what's going on? Any theories?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's, like, catastrophic by our own historical standards, isn't it? So, what's going on? Any theories?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Some folks point to, like, weak fiscal stimulus here in the US after COVID. Not enough spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Some folks point to, like, weak fiscal stimulus here in the U S after C O V I D. Not enough spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, but that doesn't really explain *productivity* though, does it? I mean, weak spending affects output and jobs, but not necessarily how efficiently we're working.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, but that doesn't really explain productivity though, does it? I mean, weak spending affects output and jobs, but not necessarily how efficiently we're working.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, exactly! But then there's the idea of tight labor markets. You know, companies can't find enough workers, so they're not investing in labor-saving tech.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, exactly! But then there's the idea of tight labor markets. You know, companies can't find enough workers, so they're not investing in labor-saving tech.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Like, you go to a US bank and there are still human tellers everywhere, but in Europe, it's all ATMs, right? Or QR code menus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like, you go to a U S bank and there are still human tellers everywhere, but in Europe, it's all A T Ms, right? Or Q R code menus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But then the article also points out that US productivity slowed *before* the pandemic too, when labor markets were super tight. So, it's not a clear-cut answer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But then the article also points out that U S productivity slowed before the pandemic too, when labor markets were super tight. So, it's not a clear-cut answer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's not. What about, um, tech adoption? Like AI and stuff? Are we just slow?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's not. What about, um, tech adoption? Like A I and stuff? Are we just slow?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article says for older digital tech, the timing's wrong. But for new stuff, like LLMs and generative AI, it takes time to reorganize. It's that "J-curve" effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article says for older digital tech, the timing's wrong. But for new stuff, like L L Ms and generative A I, it takes time to reorganize. It's that J-curve effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since...The inevitability of errors means that productivity is likely to fall before rising, a phenomenon economists call the productivity J-curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, right, the initial dip before the big gains. So, Europe just... got lucky with the energy crisis, maybe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, right, the initial dip before the big gains. So, Europe just... got lucky with the energy crisis, maybe?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Kind of. They were forced to, like, suspend energy-intensive operations or restructure, which actually made them more productive. It's a weird kind of silver lining.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kind of. They were forced to, like, suspend energy-intensive operations or restructure, which actually made them more productive. It's a weird kind of silver lining.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a combination of, uh, tight labor markets, slow tech integration, and then, like, a bit of unexpected external pressure for Europe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a combination of, uh, tight labor markets, slow tech integration, and then, like, a bit of unexpected external pressure for Europe?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Something seems to be going seriously right in the US and seriously wrong in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's a complex puzzle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's a complex puzzle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it makes you wonder what, uh, policies we need to be thinking about here to catch up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it makes you wonder what, uh, policies we need to be thinking about here to catch up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.
